prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Where confidential business information will be disclosed to third parties, consideration should be given to drafting an agreement so that those parties will be formally bound to preserve confidentiality. The advantages of a written agreement can be numerous and substantial, providing formal evidence of the duties owed by the parties, stating clearly the purpose for which the information was provided, and forming an agreement to act in a manner which preserves confidentiality. Such contractual obligations can provide protection beyond that available at common law.
Confidentiality agreements[1] and other appropriate provisions should form a key part of the supporting documentation in a number of situations, including:
corporate transactions like mergers, acquisitions and divestitures;
the retainer of consultants and advisors; and
agreements in relation to strategic alliances, joint ventures, partnerships, franchises, licences and distributorships.
Consideration should be given to at least the following issues:
limitations on the use of the information;
prohibitions on copying or other duplication;
return of the information and any copies; and
These agreements must also satisfy the normal requirements of contract law to be enforceable.
See the sample provided in Appendix A.
